Macron appoints Sébastien Lecornu as France's prime minister
subhead: One day after François Bayrou lost a vote of confidence, Emmanuel Macron asked Sébastien Lecornu, a longtime loyalist who had served as defense minister since 2022, to form a government.
byline: Le Monde with AP and AFP

'Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin share a communist fascination with combating the decay of the body'
subhead: On September 3, during a private conversation caught by a live microphone, the Russian president and his Chinese counterpart discussed the extension of life. Anthropologist Philippe Charlier explains that this exchange echoes the communist project of building a 'new man.'

title: Le Pen, facing electoral ban, gets expedited appeal trial
subhead: A Paris court has scheduled the appeal trial for her party's fake assistant jobs at the European Parliament case from January 13 to February 12, 2026. The far-right Rassemblement National criticized the timing for coming just weeks before the municipal elections.

title: France's best art exhibitions this fall, in Paris and beyond
subhead: Here is Le Monde's selection of must-see art exhibitions, from painter John Singer Sargent to medieval forgeries to contemporary Nigerian artist Otobong Nkanga, which will go on display through the end of the year.

title: Global debt, deficits and inflation put mounting pressure on interest rates
subhead: Accelerated in France by the fall of Prime Minister François Bayrou and his government, the rise in long-term interest rates is affecting most major developed countries.

Macron, a vulnerable president after one dissolution and two failed governments
subhead: The fall of Prime Minister François Bayrou ushers in a new period of political instability. The French president, widely seen as responsible for the crisis within his own ranks, now faces pressure from the opposition to propose a new candidate for the post of prime minister.
byline: By Mariama Darame and Nathalie Segaunes

title: Historian Marion Fontaine on 'Block Everything': 'It's difficult to find precedents in the long history of social movements'
subhead: Marion Fontaine, historian of social movements at the Sciences Po higher learning institute, describes the September 10 movement as a disorganized initiative that the myth of the general strike does not help clarify.
byline: Interview by Alain Beuve-Méry and Pascal Riché

title: Tradition done right: Five Paris restaurants reimagining the classics
subhead: Are you a fan of French cuisine classics such as 'œufs en meurette' (poached eggs in red wine sauce), 'navarin d'agneau' (lamb stew) and apple tart? Discover our selection of five Paris restaurants that awaken both the appetite and a sense of nostalgia.
